headline.main: Gene Therapy's Focus Shifts From Rare Illnesses

docs.abstract: Promise of gene therapy for thousands of people affected by hereditary diseases has dimmed; it has been difficult to get genes to desired cells efficiently and have them produce enough of needed protein; some patients have reported gains, but scientific evidence of consistent improvement in patients is lacking so far; for business reasons, focus of gene therapy has shifted from inherited diseases, which afflict handful to few thousand people worldwide, toward more common ailments like cancer, AIDS and heart disease, areas that could prove more profitable for pharmaceutical companies; situation raises prospect that Human Genome Project will discover abundance of genes responsible for illnesses, but that no one will actually use those genes to help patients; patient groups are raising money to finance research, including gene therapy trials; some say Government should finance clinical trials for rare diseases; but National Institutes of Health believes money should first be spent to improve basic science and technology rather than embarking on trials that probably will not be very useful; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the gene responsible for Hunter's syndrome was discovered about 10 years ago, Joan Cohen was told by a doctor that it would take only five years to develop a gene therapy for the rare hereditary disease that afflicts her son. Mrs. Cohen, who lives in Island Park, L.I., is still waiting. Even in its mild form, the disease often kills people by the time they reach 35. ''It's like a time bomb,'' Mrs. Cohen said. Her 17-year-old son, Adam, is just 4 feet 11 inches tall and suffers from leaky and enlarged heart valves, respiratory problems and deteriorated hearing. ''I'm sitting here with a kid that I know is going to die and there's nothing I can do that will stop it.''

headline.main: Indians Proudly Revive a Tradition of Running

docs.abstract: Wings of America sparks a running renaissance among Indians, whose running tradition has given way in recent decades to more sedentary ways that are blamed for high incidence of diabetes and obesity among Indians; running revival is strong around Shiprock, NM, one of Navajos' largest towns; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Against a backdrop of junked cars and sagging trailers, a long line of young Navajos set off one recent morning, running toward the East, running toward the rising sun. ''When the sun comes up, the gods come up, so we run to greet the gods in the morning,'' Kelly Upshaw, a Navajo from Fort Defiance, Ariz., said as she unwound from the run, pacing about a high school track here. ''That is how my parents taught me.''

docs.abstract: Lane Bryant introduces a new label, Venezia Jeans Clothing, offering clothes with more style than is usually found in larger sizes; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, clothing for queen-size women was often dowdy and unstylish, and Lane Bryant, the national chain store for women size 14 and up, was not exactly fashion-forward. But the company is introducing a new label, Venezia Jeans Clothing, with an emphasis on stylish looks for amply proportioned young women. The clothes are being modeled by full-figured young spokeswomen, including Mia Tyler, an actress (left); Abbie Kearses, a television reporter, and Kym Hampton of the Women's National Basketball Association. They will take part in a photo shoot and fashion show at Chelsea Piers on Tuesday. Lane Bryant said it developed the line in response to a study showing that the fastest growing market for such clothing was among women 17 to 25. No doubt they crave stylish clothes as much as anyone, but one might wonder about the message in the company's news release that ''it's phat to be fat.'' The number of overweight adolescents has more than doubled since 1965, according to the Centers for Disease Control, and doctors link obesity to health problems.
